Advancing Partners and Communities (APC) is a USAID project mechanism implemented by JSI Research and Training Institute supporting USAID Missions to to expand and extend community-based health services, to test and document best practices and models of delivery and to support global learning. APC will work with NGO networks and health services in the Dominican Republic to build technical and organizational capacity provide grants and technical assistance to support combination HIV prevention projects, referral systems for clinical services, and reaching and retaining target populations in comprehensive HIV care. Technical assistance and technically guided facilitation will lead to measurable increases in organizational and technical capacity of grantees (and other development partners, including health services) and will lead to increased coverage and quality of services for priority populations, while at the same time contributing to the sustainability of the national response to HIV. An integral element of this approach will be working in partnership with national, regional and local government authorities, NGOs and sister Health Policy Project on improving the enabling environment through community mobilization and support for structural interventions to address stigma and discrimination in health services and improve prevention of and response to violence against members of the most affected groups. The priority populations are key populations - men who have sex with men, transgender women, female sex workers; and other vulnerable populations - batey residents, clients of sex workers; especially those who are living with HIV. Partnership with the Global Fund on design, implementation and joint monitoring will be an integral element of the approach.
